   This nuclear battery could power your smartphone forever  as long as you dont value your life or sperm count too highly | ExtremeTech

  <meta content="This nuclear battery could power your smartphone forever  as long as you dont value your life or sperm count too highly | ExtremeTech" property="og:title"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" property="og:site_name"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190555-this-nuclear-battery-could-power-your-smartphone-forever-as-long-as-you-dont-value-your-life-or-sperm-count-too-highly" property="og:url"/>
  <meta content="Your next smartphone or electric vehicle might be powered by a nuclear battery instead of your usual lithium-ion cell thanks to a breakthrough made by University of Missouri researchers. This is bad news for those of you who think that WiFi signals are bad for your health -- especially if they're received by a smartphone situated near your head or gonads -- but great news for all of the people who value all-day battery life ahead of increased radiation exposure. The world could probably do with reduced fertility rates anyway, right?" property="og:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/strontium-nuclear-betavoltaic-battery.jpg" property="og:image"/>
  <meta content="summary_large_image" name="twitter:card"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" name="twitter:site"/>
  <meta content="@ExtremeTech" name="twitter:creator"/>
  <meta content="extremetech.com" name="twitter:domain"/>
  <meta content="This nuclear battery could power your smartphone forever  as long as you dont value your life or sperm count too highly | ExtremeTech" name="twitter:title"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190555-this-nuclear-battery-could-power-your-smartphone-forever-as-long-as-you-dont-value-your-life-or-sperm-count-too-highly" name="twitter:url"/>
  <meta content="Your next smartphone or electric vehicle might be powered by a nuclear battery instead of your usual lithium-ion cell thanks to a breakthrough made by University of Missouri researchers. This is bad news for those of you who think that WiFi signals are bad for your health -- especially if they're received by a smartphone situated near your head or gonads -- but great news for all of the people who value all-day battery life ahead of increased radiation exposure. The world could probably do with reduced fertility rates anyway, right?" name="twitter:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/strontium-nuclear-betavoltaic-battery.jpg" name="twitter:image:src"/>

	                 return {};
	           }

  <script src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/themes/extremetech/js/newsletter.js?ver=1418319026" type="text/javascript">
  </script>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/xmlrpc.php?rsd" rel="EditURI" title="RSD" type="application/rsd+xml"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-includes/wlwmanifest.xml" rel="wlwmanifest" type="application/wlwmanifest+xml"/>

  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/190581-nvidias-ace-in-the-hole-against-amd-maxwell-is-the-first-gpu-with-full-directx-12-support" rel="next" title="Nvidias ace in the hole against AMD: Maxwell is the first GPU with full DirectX 12 support"/>

          #stickybanner,

      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">

        <li class="current_item">
         This nuclear battery could power your smartphone forever  as long as you dont value your life or sperm count too highly
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           This nuclear battery could power your smartphone forever  as long as you dont value your life or sperm count too highly
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/santhony" rel="author" title="Posts by Sebastian Anthony">
              Sebastian Anthony
             </a>
             on September 19, 2014 at 11:38 am
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="190555 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=190555" href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190555-this-nuclear-battery-could-power-your-smartphone-forever-as-long-as-you-dont-value-your-life-or-sperm-count-too-highly#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Betavoltaic nuclear battery, featured crop" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="352" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/strontium-nuclear-betavoltaic-battery-640x352.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Your next smartphone or electric vehicle might be powered by a
            <em>
             nuclear
            </em>
            battery instead of your usuallithium-ion cellthanks to abreakthrough madebyUniversity of Missouri researchers. This is bad news for those of youwho think that WiFi signals are bad for your health  especially if theyre received by a smartphone situated near your head or gonads  but great news for all of the people who value all-day battery life ahead of increased radiation exposure. The world could probably do with reduced fertility rates anyway, right?
           </p>
           <p>
            First, just to put your mind at rest: This nuclear battery doesnt contain a mini nuclear fission reactor  that would be insane (at least given our current grasp of nuclear power generation, anyway). Instead, this battery, developed by Baek Kim and Jae Kwon at the University of Missouri, uses the
            <em>
             betavoltaic
            </em>
            process to generate electricity. A betavoltaic device, as the name implies, is fairly similar a photovoltaic device  but instead of generating electricity from photons, it generates electricity from beta radiation  i.e.high-energy electrons that are emitted by radioactive elements. A betavoltaic device is constructed in almost exactly the same way as a photovoltaic cell: a piece of silicon (or other semiconductor) is wedged between two electrodes, and when radiation hits the semiconductor it produces a flow of electrons (voltage, electricity).
           </p>
           <p>
            But surely having a battery, and thus a mobile device, packed full ofradioactive material is a bad idea I hear you say. And usually, yes, youd be right. What makes a betavoltaic battery somewhat safe is that beta radiation can be easily stopped with a thin piece of aluminium; gamma radiation, on the other hand,has so much penetrative power that it can only be stopped by a big lump of lead (or other dense metal). This doesnt mean that beta radiation in itself is safe  it can cause cancer and death  but its much easier to control. Just make sure the betavoltaic nuclear battery casing is more than a couple of millimeters thick  and dont drop it.
            <strong>
             Ever
            </strong>
            .
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_190573" style="width: 650px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/srep05249-f3.jpg">
             <img alt="University of Missouri's betavoltaic battery" class="size-large wp-image-190573" height="1428" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/srep05249-f3-640x1428.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             University of Missouris betavoltaic battery
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            Anyway, back to the University of Missouris battery. Basically, Kim and Kwons nuclear battery consists of a platinum-coated titanium dioxide electrode, water, and a piece of radioactive strontium-90. Strontium-90 (Sr-90) radioactively decays with ahalf-life of 28.79 years, producing an electron (beta radiation), an anti-neutrino, and the isotopeyttrium-90. Y-90 itself has a half-life of just 64 hours, decaying into more electrons, anti-neutrinos, and zirconium (which is stable). The best thing about using strontium-90 as a fuel is that it produces almost no gamma radiation  so, as far as radioactive materials go, its pretty safe and easy to handle. (Still, theres no avoiding the fact that its used extensively in medicine, both for radiotherapy of cancer, and as a radioactive tracer.)
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             Read:
             <a href="www.extremetech.com/extreme/130024-electroslave">
              We are slaves of electricity  and battery technology
             </a>
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            While betavoltaic batteriesare fairly old hat  they powered some of the earlier pacemakers, before more advanced chemistries such as lithium-ion arrived  the Missouri researchers say that their addition of water is a key breakthrough. Not only does water absorb a lot of the energy of the beta radiation (in high quantities its damaging to the betavoltaic semiconductor), but the beta radiation also splits the water molecules, producing free radicals and electricity.
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_190572" style="width: 650px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/srep05249-f2.jpg">
             <img alt="The nanostructured titanium dioxide electrode" class="size-large wp-image-190572" height="179" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/srep05249-f2-640x179.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             The nanostructured titanium dioxide electrode (left), and then after it has been coated with platinum (mid).
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            Water acts as a buffer and surface plasmons created in the device turned out to be very useful in increasing its efficiency,
            <a href="http://munews.missouri.edu/news-releases/2014/0916-first-water-based-nuclear-battery-developed-by-mu-researcher-can-be-used-to-generate-electrical-energy/">
             Kwon says
            </a>
            . The ionic solution is not easily frozen at very low temperatures and could work in a wide variety of applications, including car batteries and, if packaged properly, perhaps spacecraft. [Research paper:
            <a href="http://www.nature.com/srep/2014/140611/srep05249/full/srep05249.html">
             doi:10.1038/srep05249
            </a>
            - "Plasmon-assisted radiolytic energy conversion in aqueous solutions"]
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignright" id="attachment_184139" style="width: 310px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/fuel-rods.jpg">
             <img alt="Stored nuclear fuel rods glow an eery, distinctive blue." class="size-medium wp-image-184139" height="198" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/fuel-rods-300x198.jpg" width="300"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             Will your next smartphone glow blue like these stored nuclear fuel rods? Probably not.
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            Ultimately, even if beta radiation can be quite easily contained, I doubt well ever see commercial nuclear batteries.Those headlines about exploding lithium-ion batteries are already scary enough; I cant imagine Apple or Samsung will ever open themselves up to even worse headlines/lawsuits. (Smartphone owner dies from acute radiation sickness after dropping his phone.) Theres also the distinct possibility of terrorists creating a dirty bomb from all of that strontium-90 (which itself isnt cheap, incidentally).
           </p>
           <p>
            For now, nuclear batteries will probably only be used in military and space applications, where extreme longevity outweighs any risks. Still, its nice to dream of a smartphone or other mobile device that never once needs recharging
           </p>
           <p>
           </p>
           <p>
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">

            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',

        placement: 'Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">
          <div class="widget column widget_tagswidget" id="tagswidget-2">

           </div>

           <script type="text/javascript">
            var disqus_developer = 1;
           </script>
           <div class="title">
            <span class="count">

             </a>
            </span>
            <h3>
             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>
           <div id="disqus_thread">

             <ul id="dsq-comments">

                     <p>
                      The amount of radiation required to sterilize you is greater than the amount needed to kill you.  About 550 rads to kill and about 635 to sterilize.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">

                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-373028">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-373028">

                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332363">

                    The tritium is contained in a glass capsule that had a phosphorescent coating on the inside that emits photons when his with the radioactive decay. That radiation isnt strong enough to penetrate the glass.
                   </p>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-331981">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331981">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-331981">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-331981">
                          Marc Guillot
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331981">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331981">
                         <p>
                          How much do you pay over 10 years in gasoline ?. This combustible price can go pretty high and still be worth it.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-332689">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332689">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-332689">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-332689">
                          Marco
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332689">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332689">
                         <p>
                          I can tell you that I personally spend approximately $2,500 per year on gasoline.  The amount of SR-90 needed to produce power in this way is not stated in the article, nor did I see it mentioned in the paper, but it is pretty safe to assume (from current use in a few specialized applications) that you need a lot to create enough power for a car.  The Mars rover Curiosity is running around with an 11 pound block of plutonium inside it, and that produces about 125 watts of power.  A car needs a lot more power than that (even the stock speakers in a Tesla Model X take 200 watts), as even the electric motor in a Prius uses up to 30,000 watts.  Now that is peak, so for an average number lets take that down a lot, to say 10,000 watts to operate a vehicle on average (and assume the peaks can be taken up by batteries).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          To make a simple and basic guess, if we assume a linear relationship between the plutonium and power output, youd need almost a 900 pound block of plutonium to power a Prius. Lets assume (big assumption) that this new technique (from the article) can make the whole thing almost twice as efficient than using the plutonium, and  so we only need 500 pounds of SR90 for each new car built.  Current prices on SR-90 are hard to find, but tend to be orders of magnitude more expensive than say bulk uranium.  Ive seen old references that price it at $400 an ounce.  If thats still the case, a car needing 500 pounds would need $3.2 million in SR-90.  But the world currently builds 65 million new cars a year (increasing that 2 million per year), so youd need an extra 16 million tonnes a year of SR-90 to put it in all new cars.  Needless to say, for an expensive and limited item such as SR-90, that would jack up the price insanely.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333332">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333332">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333332">
                         http://batman-news.com
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333332">
                          Andrew Dodson
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333332">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333332">
                         <p>
                          All sources I have read state that Sr-90 is cheap and readily available.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333337">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333337">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333337">
                         http://batman-news.com
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333337">
                          Andrew Dodson
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333337">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333337">
                         <p>
                          I wonder if Strontium-90 or another betavoltaic would produce enough power to reasonably run a car. LETS GO VISIT THE BACK OF THE ENVELOPE!
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          You would want to get by with refueling once every 15-20
                          <br/>
                          years, and would need to generate around 10 kW (around 13hp) .. At 60 mph, a typical car needs 10 to 20 horsepower simply to maintain its speed. You would use an ultracapacitor (10-20 kW per kg) to provide for regenerative breaking and acceleration, most likely rated at 100kW (at 10-20 kW per kg) for another 5-10 kg.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Strontium-90 also requires little shielding, as it decays
                          <br/>
                          by  emission, with negligible  emission. While its half life of 28.8 years is much shorter than that of Pu-238, it also has a much lower decay energy. Thus its power density is only 0.46 kilowatts per kilogram. Because the energy output is lower it reaches lower temperatures than Pu-238, which results in lower RTG efficiency. Sr-90 is a high yield waste product of nuclear fission and is available in large quantities at a low price.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Ok so we need around 26 kg of Strontium with a 100%
                          <br/>
                          efficient converter, but the one developed in Missouri recently is only 60% efficient, so that gets bumped up to 43.3kg, which is just under 100 lbs of Strontium. This would be about the size of one large barbell plate. You might consider that the carbon electrode, casing, and ultracapacitor weigh that much again, for an entire power train of slightly under 200 lbs. This is easily equivalent to the weight of an internal combustion engine, cooling system, and drive train. Add another 110 lbs of electric motor, as the TransWarP 7, capable of driving up to 1500 lbs. of vehicle weight. This gives us a total budget of around 1000 lbs for the vehicle frame and passengers, a nice amount.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Just for reference, the battery pack in a tesla roadster
                          <br/>
                          weighs 1000 lbs. by itself!! (seems rather large, did not verify source)
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          WOOHOO I BEAT TESLA. You can have an electric car that
                          <br/>
                          never needs charging, and starts off with a boost charge whenever you have left the car sitting for a small amount of time for the capacitor to become fully charged. Any where you drive to, you could plug into your car when it was not being driven to run any kinds of appliances, even electric grills and large sound systems.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          You would need a method to deal with the heat generated, but this level of heat is comparable to what is produced in an  equivalent combustion engine.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          An appropriate radiator would be sufficient, but hopefully would only be required when the car was off and not being used; improving aerodynamics.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Ideally the vehicle would most times be either plugged into the grid producing power consistently, being driven, or having its power used in a remote location.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Strontium is in all nuclear waste and we could obtain it cheaply enough if we actually had a sensible nuclear program to produce the material. Note how Sr-90 actually beats lithium batteries soundly. Our ability to increase from 20% to 60% energy density is a tripling of the power density, easily moving Sr-90 past lithium, which allows for a lower total weight when combined with the appropriate capacitive storage. Heres some good cost numbers for reference:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://large.stanford.edu/courses/2011/ph240/kumar2/" rel="nofollow">
                           http://large.stanford.edu/courses/2011/ph240/kumar2/
                          </a>
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333342">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333342">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333342">
                         http://batman-news.com
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333342">
                          Andrew Dodson
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333342">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333342">
                         <p>
                          $2500 yearly corresponds to about a tank of gas per week, so a moderately amount of driving.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          so the target price per kg we would have to achieve with strontium would be (15 years of fuel * $2500 of fuel/yr = $37,500) divided by the kgs of Sr-90 required: ~45.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Thus a dollar amount of $833 per kg would be break even. We would want to be under this number significantly to allow for the cost difference in the structured collector as proposed here. Very feasible though and super enviro friendly.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          After 15 years roughly 25% of your Sr-90 would have decayed to Zirconium, itself a valuable metal. At this point it would be reprocessed into a new nuclear fuel cell.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Can I have my future already? Please stop condemning us to a bland boorish smoggy future you fossil fuel companies.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333485">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333485">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333485">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333485">
                          Marco
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333485">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333485">
                         <p>
                          I want a great future too.  But dreamy possibilities, practical reality, and real events are 3 different things.  So lets stop fooling ourselves and look at a few numbers to help clear away some of the unknowns:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Price check on Sr-90, please!  This presentation from the university of wisconsin (
                          <a href="http://fti.neep.wisc.edu/neep602/SPRING00/lecture5.pdf" rel="nofollow">
                           http://fti.neep.wisc.edu/neep602/SPRING00/lecture5.pdf
                          </a>
                          ) shows (page 19) it is one of the cheapest RTG materials, but still costs $20/gram.  If you want a 45 kg (45,000 grams) block of the stuff, youll be paying 45,000 * 20, or roughly $900,000 for that block.  Good luck.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The expense is also borne out in page 20 of the UW presentation, where it shows an estimated cost of $6 per kWh for electricity from Sr-90.  Still far cheaper than most RTG fuels, but at that price it costs you over $500 every time you fully charge your 85 kWh Tesla battery.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Oh, and about the 45 kg weight youre dreaming if you think 60% efficiency is even possible, much less practical, for an RTG.  The newest materials have a theoretical efficiency as high as 40%, but an acknowledged practical efficiency far below that.  Most RTGs operate in the 3% to 7% range right now, with 10% being a max real-life top end.  So 60% is just not feasible for any calculation, back of the napkin or otherwise.  You really shouldnt estimate for more than 20%, double todays best, 4 times todays reality.  That means youd really need 3 times the Sr-90, or 135kg based on your calcs, costing $2.7 million at todays prices.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And about those prices.  Lets go back to the Wisconsin presentation and look at supply on page 18.  Supply is more or less fixed as Sr-90 comes from nuclear power plants.  The UW presentation shows a figure of 16 kg/1000 MWeY.  Currently about 435 nuclear plants worldwide operate with a capacity of 375,000 MWe of capacity.  Assuming they all operate at 100% for the year (they are baseline power, after all), youd be looking at 375 * 16 or 6,000 kg a year of Sr-90 produced if it can all be recovered.  If even only 1% of the 65 million new cars produced each year used Sr-90 for power, and even if they really did only use 45kg that you claimed earlier, youd still need to produce over 29 million kg a year just for that.  Thats about 5,000 times what is currently produced.  Just for 1% of new cars.  Can you imagine what that would do to the price of Sr-90?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Lastly, let me touch on your comment that Sr-90 decays to Zirconium.  Firstly, it decays to Yttrium 90 (
                          <a href="http://periodictable.com/Isotopes/038.90/index.full.html" rel="nofollow">
                           http://periodictable.com/Isotopes/038.90/index.full.html
                          </a>
                          ) which is valuable for cancer treatments of radiation therapy, has a 64 hour half life, and is obtained through chemical seperation from Sr-90.  It is very expensive already, and creating large demands on Sr-90 would remove it as a cancer treatment for just about everybody.  So lets be aware of these unintended consequences.  Once the Y-90 decays, it does indeed become Zr-90.  Zr-90 is stable, and therefore not used for nuclear power.  It is also a fairly common metal, which sells for as little as $60 per kg right now, which is about twice the price of cobalt, so really not all that expensive.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Bottom line is that this just wont be feasible for large scale (auto) production in the real world.  I too want the great techs the future will bring.  But some of these ideas are just so pie-in-the-sky.  Lets take the realistic incremental steps to get where we want to be, not waste time hoping for things that cannot be.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333891">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333891">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333891">
                         http://batman-news.com
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333891">
                          Andrew Dodson
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333891">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333891">
                         <p>
                          I think that Sr-90 would be a readily available isotope if we actually got most of our electricity from nuclear like we should. Using ionic liquid chemistry techniques we COULD seperate out the Sr-90 inexpensively.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          But I do agree with you, that in the existing paradigm, it will never happen. The post was meant as a rough example of what is enabled by increasing the efficiency of a betavoltaic system by the magnitude of what has been developed at Missouri.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I am confused why you are quoting the much lower efficiency numbers for RTGs This article is about a novel betavoltaic collector with efficiency around 60% if I have read correctly?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333996">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333996">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333996">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333996">
                          Marco
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333996">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333996">
                         <p>
                          I agree with you completely that we should get most of our electricity from nuclear.  The world currently generates about 1/8th of its power from nuclear.  So even if we generated it all with nuclear, wed only produce 48,000 kg a year right now.  That would certainly bring prices down, assuming no major increase in current demand, and maybe better techniquies could extract it with less cost.  But the massive amounts required for cars (or even for billions of personal electronic devices) would certainly outstrip demand.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And youre right that we should use the betavoltaic efficiencies rather than those of RTGs.  The one mentioned here states that is has a max efficiency of about 53% in their lab.  Though we should drop that for real world conditions, it is probably safe to assume that at some point an efficiency between 40% and 50% would be possible in a real world product.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I wonder how much water is used in the process since it splits the water.  And if there are any issues with byproducts (O &amp; H) being stored or released, if beta radiation has to be contained, etc.  Hopefully the amount of water needed would be small enough to not be of major consequence.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-351934">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-351934">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-351934">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-351934">
                          Paul Davis
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-351934">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-351934">
                         <p>
                          Smallest reactors yet made used americium and produced about 140kw.  To make one yet smaller youd have to use some kind of particle accelerator to push the reaction.  Doing this as a 10 KW reactor (yes, a tesla CAN draw 30kw, but doesnt do this constantly, most of the time it is just cruising, you charge a capacitor or battery store to balance the load) is probably possible, but might not be desirable.  Besides, youd have to use a relatively short half life material, which would mean refueling every few years or months.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-331977">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331977">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-331977">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-331977">
                        Marc Guillot
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331977">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331977">
                       <p>
                        Strontium-90 is a waste product of our current nuclear plants. We can ensure a pretty steady supply of it.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-332411">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332411">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-332411">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-332411">
                          Fanandala
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332411">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332411">
                         <p>
                          It may be a waste product but to isolate it from the other waste is obviously not quite cheap.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-331925">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331925">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-331925">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-331925">
                    massau
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331925">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331925">
                   <p>
                    The power usage of a car is huge compared to a phone. its horse power *1.34kW so an 60HP car will use 80 kW of power.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    so unless you find a way to make cars much much lighter to give them a decent KW/kg ratio you will be unable to use this tech.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    for electrical bicycles and velomobiles this might be useful. i wonder what the power density of these batteries are.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332002">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332002">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332002">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332002">
                      VirtualMark
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332002">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332002">
                     <p>
                      So why not use a bigger battery?
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-332004">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332004">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-332004">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-332004">
                        massau
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332004">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332004">
                       <p>
                        More battery is more weight. if this battery can only deliver 2 watt per 100g* it would make a 10 watt phone &gt;500g which is reasonable.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        But for a 80kW car we would require a 4 ton battery. To give it in perspective the average car weights 1.5 ton.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        so to put a number on it the car would weight
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        5 ton and only have 60HP/5ton which is 12HP/ton do you would be driving a minivan and have the speed of a snail.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        *i made this up so it can be different but i looks reasonable to me so if i get real data i will update you.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-332010">

                          So youre assuming that it only produces 2 watts per kilo?  Why are you assuming this?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333894">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333894">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333894">

                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333894">

                         </span>

                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333894">

                         </p>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->

                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-332012">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332012">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-332012">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-332012">
                        massau
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332012">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332012">
                       <p>
                        (i comment a second time because i have no way to know if you read my previous comment or not but where are the details google gave me)
                        <br/>
                        first of all im sorry Sebastian i have to break your dream [and article] ,I wish you better luck with the microfusioncell.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        first off power density for nickel63 it would be 5 watt/kg in radiation power, The efficiency at the moment of these batteries are slightly more then 20%. so a 5 watt battery would require 5kg off radioactive material (which is enough for a dirty bomb).
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The total battery would be significantly heavier with its required semiconductors and shielding.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        off course you could couple a small lithium ion battery to the radioactive battery so the phone charges when in deep sleep mode.
                        <br/>
                        But that a  calculate for an other comment because i do not know the power consumption of the phone at all its idle states and average usage.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        tritium might be better but this is for the next comment.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        source power ratio.
                        <br/>
                        <a href="http://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/83821/why-arent-betavoltaics-and-alphavoltaics-batteries-widely-used" rel="nofollow">
                         http://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/83821/why-arent-betavoltaics-and-alphavoltaics-batteries-widely-used
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        <a href="http://ceramics.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/international_kherani2.pdf" rel="nofollow">
                         http://ceramics.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/international_kherani2.pdf
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        efficiency for the battery.
                        <br/>
                        <a href="http://cap.ee.ic.ac.uk/~pdm97/powermems/2009/pdfs/papers/050_0154.pdf" rel="nofollow">
                         http://cap.ee.ic.ac.uk/~pdm97/powermems/2009/pdfs/papers/050_0154.pdf
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        <a href="http://www.google.com/patents/US20110298071" rel="nofollow">
                         http://www.google.com/patents/US20110298071
                        </a>
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-332020">

                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332417">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-332417">

                        massau

                      </cite>

                <!-- #comment-## -->

               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-331904">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331904">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-331904">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-331904">
                  RH
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331904">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331904">
                 <p>
                  Neat idea, but as scientifically ignorant as most people are, I dont see it happening.  People hear the word nuclear and always see a huge a-bomb cloud.  Nuclear, done right is cheaper, more powerful, and has less impact on the environment than coal, oil, batteries.  I grew up not far from Columbia, Mo.  I bet 75% of the people around there have no idea the University of Missouri Columbia has a nuclear reactor.  Theyve had it for around 40 years.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  South of the football stadium where they use to have tailgating parties, off the road is a small research reactor.  University of Missouri Rolla has one too, for the same purpose.  Nuclear is a great resource, but movies like The China Syndrome, Three Mile Island (even though no fallout ever escaped), and Chernobyl have stopped more expansion of nuclear power.  Chernobyl was a disaster, because the old Soviet way of doing things lead to the accident.  TMI the safeguards WORKED.  beta radiation can be contained, not gamma (easily).
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-331933">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331933">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-331933">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-331933">
                    Donk970
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331933">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331933">
                   <p>
                    Absolutely right.  While we certainly need to do a better job of regulating the nuclear industry we also need to build more nuclear plants.  Another important consideration is that the only place to get strontium-90 is from the waste from a fission power plant.  Ive been very intrigued by the molten salt reactor designs which we were working on back in the 60s, particularly the LFTRs.  Nixon nixed the program because they didnt produce bomb materials which I see as a major endorsement for a civilian power plant design.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-331949">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331949">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-331949">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-331949">
                      boron
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331949">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331949">
                     <p>
                      do a better job of regulating the nuclear industry its already more regulated than the railroads
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      If you bother reading the history, youll find out why Nixon nixed the program
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-331943">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331943">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-331943">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-331943">
                    massau
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331943">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331943">
                   <p>
                    I guess the government should have never sold the nuclear power plants they build them and eventually sold them. But the government still has all the costs of getting the fuel at the reactors and non of the profits of the reactor itself.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    they could close the old bad ones in a year and use that year to build fewer bigger and more efficient ones.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332403">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332403">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332403">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332403">
                      Fanandala
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332403">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332403">
                     <p>
                      The government has been receiving 0.1 cent per kWh produced by every nuclear power plant. This was supposed to finance a final storage site for spent fuel (Yucca mountain). Billions were spent on it and then it was politically blocked. The nuclear industry is the only one that takes care and pays for its waste product.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332090">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332090">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332090">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332090">
                    Kakkoii
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332090">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332090">
                   <p>
                    I wonder what the energy cost for launching our radioactive waste into space or the sun would be. Rocket technology is becoming cheaper, that reusable rocket from SpaceX could be used to repeatedly carry waste into space and come back safely. The fuel cost though, I wonder how much of the nuclear plants energy output would be negated by the energy spent launching its waste into space
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332110">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332110">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332110">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332110">
                      CPPCrispy
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332110">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332110">
                     <p>
                      I think this would be a very bad idea. Can you imagine what would happen if a rocket failed during launch? It would be a government sanctioned dirty bomb. Also what would happen if it fell back to earth and burned up on reentry? It would literally be raining radiation.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332288">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332288">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332288">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332288">
                      Asteroid Miner
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332288">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332288">
                     <p>
                      Spent nuclear fuel is recyclable.  That is why we dont dump it in the ocean.  We want to keep it until the price of uranium goes up.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      In the 1960s, we recycled spent nuclear fuel.  We dont recycle nuclear fuel now because it is valuable and people steal it.  The place it went that it wasnt supposed to go to was Israel.  This happened in a small town near Pittsburgh, PA circa 1970.   A company called Numec was in the business of reprocessing nuclear fuel.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      [I almost took a job there in 1968, designing a nuclear battery for a heart pacemaker.  [A nuclear battery would have the advantage of lasting many times as long as any other battery, eliminating many surgeries to replace batteries.]]
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Spent fuel should be recycled, not stored.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Numec did not have a reactor.  Numec lost some nuclear fuel.  It wound up in Israel.  The Israelis fueled their nuclear short cycle plutonium239 plant to make their nuclear weapons by stealing nuclear waste.  Notice they had to fuel a short-cycle reactor to MAKE Pu239.  Pure Pu239 does not come directly from spent fuel.  7% plutonium240 spoils the plutonium and makes it useless for bomb making.  Powerplant reactors make mostly bad [for making bombs] isotopes of plutonium.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      My solution would be to reprocess the fuel at a Government Owned Government Operated [GOGO] facility.  At a GOGO plant, bureaucracy and the multiplicity of ethnicities and religions would disable the transportation of uranium to Israel or to any unauthorized place.  Nothing heavier than a secret would get out.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      The problem is political:  The Republicans think GOGO plants are socialist/communist, which is nonsense.  If a COCO [Contractor Owned Contractor Operated] plant is the low bidder, it is inevitably a front for Israel or some other country.  We could send our spent fuel to France, Japan or Russia to be recycled.  Those countries have recycling facilities.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-332449">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332449">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-332449">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-332449">
                        P.B. Lecavalier
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332449">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332449">
                       <p>
                        Its more about the relative price of uranium vs. that of solutions like PRISM reactors than the price of uranium alone. It could be done much faster if governments wake up and observe that it would be in itself a sufficient reason to begin reducing their stocks of used fuel. Lots of opposition to nuclear stem from the mere existence of nuclear waste. Opposition to kill existing waste and make energy from it? Ignore them.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        In fact, the biggest obstacle is a short supply (or zero supply) of long-term vision. As you said, its not an economic problem, but a political one.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>

                 </p>

               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-331941">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331941">

                   </p>

                <!-- #comment-## -->

               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-331947">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331947">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-331947">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-331947">
                  Donk970
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331947">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331947">
                 <p>
                  The reason we will dither over how to solve the global warming crisis for the next fifty years and ultimately not solve it is our basic ignorance about nuclear, photo voltaic and wind.   We, as a people, ignorantly believe that we will somehow be able to generate all the electricity we need simply by papering the world over with solar panels and bird blenders while going into a panic every time we hear the phrase nuclear energy.   While its true that we could handle a lot of our peak day time power load with solar panels on our roofs we still need a way to supply our base load.  Solar and wind are inherently intermittent and unreliable.  Nuclear, on the other hand, is very reliable and with modern designs very safe.  The only reason that people generally consider nuclear unsafe is that as far as most people are concerned scientific and engineering progress on nuclear power plant design stopped fifty years ago when the Chernobyl power plant was built.  Thats like basing your opinion of cell phones on the old rotary phones that were around 50 years ago.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-331958">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-331958">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-331958">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-331958">
                    boron
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-331958">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-331958">
                   <p>
                    Right on!  The Luddites continue to prevail and science education in grade school and high school is all about green
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332036">

                    massau

                   <p>
                    the problem is that unlike the old rotery phones there are still a lot of nuclear power plants from 30 to 50 years old these have to be closed one way or an other. But yea i suggest putting less but bigger (&gt;1 GW instead of 200MW) and safer ones instead.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    But to be really fair our science nor our culture is ready for a safe nuclear fission power and maybe we never will be.

                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332088">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332088">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332088">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332088">
                    Kakkoii
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332088">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332088">
                   <p>
                    The height of wind turbines make them fairly reliable actually. But yes, nuclear is still the future, nuclear fusion especially, and that is why there is still a lot of active research and experimentation going on in the nuclear field. It would be great if we could get a space race style commitment from the worlds governments towards it, but its unlikely to happen.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    It seems as though for now, wind and solar are starting to supplement our energy needs enough to give us the time to develop better nuclear technologies. And is allowing for an environment where electric cars are finally starting to take hold (thanks mostly to the very generous Elon Musk and all his hard work).
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-333112">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333112">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-333112">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-333112">
                      Donk970
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333112">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333112">
                     <p>
                      I absolutely think that wind and solar will cover a lot of our peak power use but you are right that nuclear is the only way to handle the base load.  There are so many promising technologies in the nuclear field.  MSRs, LFTRs and even CANDU reactors are very promising on the fission side and LENR is looking very interesting on the fusion side.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332151">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332151">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332151">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332151">
                    Dunbar
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332151">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332151">
                   <p>
                    People consider nuclear unsafe because of the waste generated by previous generations of fission reactors. The sheer amount of waste, and the costs of storing and monitoring it safely, is staggering. Nuclear energy has a massive PR problem in some countries, but not in others. The majority of Frances energy is generated by nuclear plants, without much fuss.  The French nuclear backbone supports the European integrated energy network, it supplements nations with systems reliant on renewable sources during peak time. The renewable/nuclear network already exists and works well.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Renewable technology development is moving at great speed; the current generation of solar collectors produced by IBM have an 83% efficiency making it cheaper than oil, coal, gas and nuclear, but,  the problem of energy storage remains. If we can crack the storage problem then the need for an expensive centralized nuclear generating capacity, for domestic markets, will be moot.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332291">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332291">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332291">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332291">
                      Asteroid Miner
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332291">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332291">
                     <p>
                      BATTERIES  NOT  INCLUDED
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Reference:  bravenewclimate.com/2011/10/29/gws-sg-es/
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Geographical wind smoothing, supergrids and energy storage
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      bravenewclimate.com/2011/11/13/energy-storage-dt/#more-5281
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      ssis.arts.unsw.edu.au/tsw/RE.html
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      RENEWABLE ENERGY  CANNOT SUSTAIN AN ENERGY-INTENSIVE SOCIETY.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      bravenewclimate.com/2011/07/03/lacklustre-colorado-solar/
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Be sure to read the linked papers.  In the Arizona desert, solar has dropouts in mid day for no apparent reason.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Wind:  There are rare places where wind works locally, but to power, all of Europe, all of Europe and all of Asia has to be linked into one very expensive grid.  You need the nameplate power times 4 spread over 12 time zones to get reliable power.  The line losses are huge unless you have a superconducting grid, and superconductors now available require liquid nitrogen cooling.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      bravenewclimate.com/2012/02/27/100-renewable-electricity-for-australia-response-to-lang/
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Nuclear is the only non-CO2 making electricity source that actually works in all weather everywhere.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      GVEA s Fairbanks battery bank keeps lights on
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      newsminer.com/view/full_story/12739242/article-GVEA-s-Fairbanks-battery-bank-keeps-lights-on?
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Fairbanks, AK spent $35 million in 2003 for a battery backup that can keep the power on in Fairbanks for 7 or 15 minutes.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Energy Storage Discussion Thread
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      bravenewclimate.com/2011/11/13/energy-storage-dt/
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-332370">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332370">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-332370">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-332370">
                        Dunbar
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332370">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332370">
                       <p>
                        The renewable/nuclear integrated energy network already exists. Its not speculation, its not pontification, its not an imagined utopia in the distant future; its a messy, piecemeal, ad hoc, system built over many decades and it exists right now!
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Its apparent you failed to notice my stress on the term domestic with reference to energy consumption.  Our current renewable generating capability is not reliable enough for industrial, nor mission critical, applications. This is why we still have coal, gas and nuclear underpinning the European power grid. But, there is a commitment by the major EU economies to deploy renewable technology in its current form, and its getting results.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        In the first half of 2014 Germany generated 32% of its energy from renewables, coal and gas reliance fell  (this is after a brief increase to bridge the gap to renewables). Germany is committed to near 100% renewable energy production for its domestic market by 2020, and its ahead of schedule. Iceland is already there, they generate 100% of their electricity from hydro and geothermal sources.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The achievements so far have come at a cost; much of the technology had to be developed from scratch, which has proven expensive.  The European taxpayer, and the electricity customer, has  footed the bill; but, there is support from the public and the investments in renewables are already paying off: new industries have emerged and economies of scale are finally reducing prices.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The technology of renewable energy is moving rapidly; most the statistics published by sceptics regarding renewables does not take this into account. Reports issued by sceptics are usually out of date before theyre even published, Im not joking either.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Yes, experimental superconducting power lines are already in use in Europe and the US, and they are cheaper and more efficient than current high voltage cables.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-332402">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332402">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-332402">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-332402">
                          Fanandala
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332402">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332402">
                         <p>
                          You should never mention Germany as an example for renewable energy. They are burning more coal now than in 1990. The whole idea has become so expensive that a percentage of households is complaining about energy poverty.
                          <br/>
                          Germany is committed to near 100% renewable energy production for its domestic market by 2020, and its ahead of schedule.
                          <br/>
                          This statement is wrong.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-332475">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332475">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-332475">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-332475">
                          Dunbar
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332475">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332475">
                         <p>
                          Your opinion on Germany isnt wrong, its simply out of date.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Yes, renewables have been costly to develop. Yes, Germany expanded its fossil fuel energy production after the  pledge to end nuclear generation. Yes, Germany ramped up coal burning while renewable sources were developed
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Now coal generation has shrunk back to 2010 levels, and is set to collapse as renewables undercut it in the market. Renewables are now cheaper than coal and Germany is a net exporter of energy.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/14/science/earth/sun-and-wind-alter-german-landscape-leaving-utilities-behind.html?module=Search&amp;mabReward=relbias%3Ar%2C" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/14/science/earth/sun-and-wind-alter-german-landscape-leaving-utilities-behind.html?module=Search&amp;mabReward=relbias%3Ar%2C
                          </a>
                          {%222%22%3A%22RI%3A17%22}&amp;_r=0
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333054">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333054">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333054">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333054">
                          Fanandala
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333054">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333054">
                         <p>
                          My opinion on Germany is pretty realistic. Of course I am not wearing green tinted glasses. But if you are really interested read this
                          <br/>
                          http://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Germany-Set-To-Miss-2022-Climate-Targets-As-Coal-Use-Increases.html
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          If you do not believe that, google the Fraunhofer Institutes take on German energy production and consumption.  I would say they are the ultimate authority on the subject.
