                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333618">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333618">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333618">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333618">
                          Dunbar
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333618">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333618">
                         <p>
                          Er the article you linked to failed to mention a crucial fact: the new coal power stations that are being brought online utilize clean coal technology, up to 90% of carbon can be captured before it enters the atmosphere. As the new plants start opening the old polluting ones are mothballed.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://insideclimatenews.org/news/20130724/why-germanys-greenest-city-building-coal-fired-power-plant" rel="nofollow">
                           http://insideclimatenews.org/news/20130724/why-germanys-greenest-city-building-coal-fired-power-plant
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The German Government planned to open more coal burning stations to bridge the gap left by the scrapped nuclear stations, this is no secret. But, critics have conveniently ignored the fact the new coal power stations are very different to the old ones.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Also, the Fraunhofer institute are committed to developing renewable energy:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.ise.fraunhofer.de/en" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.ise.fraunhofer.de/en
                          </a>
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333761">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333761">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333761">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333761">
                          Fanandala
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333761">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333761">
                         <p>
                          The article does not mention carbon capture and storage. Sure they clean up the power station emissions. So far CCS is only used in some experimental setups, and people have already protested against carbon disposal in their backyards.
                          <br/>
                          The Fraunhofer Institute is pro renewables. After all they are financed by the government. If the German rate payer can afford them is another question.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333764">

                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333764">

                         <p>
                          Well, renewables are now cheaper than coal or nuclear; I guess their investment paid off.
                         </p>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333815">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333815">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333815">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333815">
                          Fanandala
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333815">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333815">
                         <p>
                          Yes it is so cheap, that the wholesale price for electricity from Canadas nuclear power stations is cheaper than the Energiewendezulage Germans have to pay on already high electricity prices.
                          <br/>
                          It is so cheap, that quite a percentage of Germans are suffering from energy poverty.
                          <br/>
                          When I dispute one of your statements and show you up wrong you just pop up with another fact or should I rather call it what  it is  fabrication. To fathom how much renewable electricity costs is virtually impossible with all the subsidies and preferential treatment it is getting.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-333820">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333820">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-333820">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-333820">
                          Dunbar
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333820">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333820">
                         <p>
                          Yes, of course energy bills went up. The green levy  means German bills are 40% above the European average; but, one benefit of the higher costs is the drive to save energy: domestic energy use has dropped 10% since 2005. Despite the increase in domestic bills, wholesale energy prices in Germany have dropped by 60% since 2008; in time, as the economy transitions to renewables, these savings will be passed on to the consumer.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          As the title of the Bloomberg article bellow states, Germanys green energy initiative has been an expensive success:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2014-09-22/germany-s-green-energy-is-an-expensive-success" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2014-09-22/germany-s-green-energy-is-an-expensive-success
                          </a>
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-333111">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333111">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-333111">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-333111">
                      Donk970
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333111">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333111">
                     <p>
                      What do you mean by sheer amount of waste?  Can you quantify that?  Is it billions of tones?  Millions?  Thousands?  How much volume?  Are we talking mountains?   How does the amount of radioactive waste introduced into the environment by a nuclear power plant compare to the amount from a coal power plant.  What about new reactor designs that could be powered with all that sheer amount of waste that we have sitting around?   Wouldnt it be a win win if we could generate power and reduce the amount of waste we have to deal with?   The nuclear power question isnt a simple one but the math is pretty clear.  A nuclear reaction produces a million times more energy than a chemical reaction so the problems of waste handling are there but the amount of energy produced per ton of waste is orders of magnitude larger for nuclear compared to coal.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-333388">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333388">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-333388">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-333388">
                        Dunbar
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333388">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333388">
                       <p>
                        Why do you mention coal? I cant see anyone defending coal.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The amount of known nuclear waste in terms of weight is around 250,000 metric tonnes. The majority is low level waste with no apparent application in energy production. It will remain hazardous and require storage and monitoring, at a cost, for between 100 and 500 hundred years. A small proportion of the waste (around 3%) will take over 10,000 years to decay. Some of the waste can already be used in the current generation of Breeder reactors, but, processing the waste is expensive; more expensive than extracting uranium from the ground. Yes, Im sure new technology will emerge to burn, or transmute,  our current nuclear waste, but currently, it does not exist.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        btw, if you care to read my post youll see Im pro-nuclear; it is essential for our current integrated energy network. Nuclear is the only carbon free method of generating electricity on demand. Unfortunately, nuclear is currently the most expensive option (if decommissioning and waste storage costs are factored in).
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332107">

                   </p>

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332168">

                  re-inventing old tech really..  They used to use betavoltaic cells in some of the old pacemakers.   They ended up dropping them because they were too efficient, went with other styles that you had to replace hence more monies being spent.
                 </p>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332174">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332174">

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332285">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332285">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332285">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332285">
                  Asteroid Miner
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332285">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332285">
                 <p>
                  In a small town near Pittsburgh, PA circa 1970,  a company called Numec was in the business of reprocessing spent nuclear fuel.   I almost took a job there in 1968, designing a nuclear battery for a heart pacemaker.   [A nuclear battery would have the advantage of lasting many times as long as any other battery, eliminating many surgeries to replace batteries.]  Numec actually did make and sell some nuclear waste powered heart pacemakers and they were implanted in human heart patients.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Sebastian Anthony:  Quit the hysteria.  Havent you ever heard of NATURAL BACKGROUND RADIATION?  Sebastian Anthony is and always has been radioactive.  Sebastian Anthony would be dead if Sebastian Anthony was NOT radioactive because minerals such as potassium that are essential for life are naturally radioactive.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332399">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332399">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332399">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332399">
                    Fanandala
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332399">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332399">
                   <p>
                    Its OK, I can make and sell him a tinfoil hat.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332286">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332286">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332286">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332286">
                  Asteroid Miner
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332286">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332286">
                 <p>
                  WHERE DID NATURAL BACKGROUND RADIATION COME FROM?
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The visible universe [ignoring dark matter and dark energy] started out with only 3 elements: hydrogen, helium and lithium.  All other elements were made in stars or by supernova explosions.  Our star is a seventh generation star.  The previous 6 generations were necessary for the elements heavier than lithium to be built up.  Since heavier elements were built by radiation processes, they were very radioactive when first made.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Our planet was made of the debris of a supernova explosion that happened about 5 billion years ago.  The Earth has been decreasing in radioactivity ever since.  All elements heavier than nickel were necessarily made by accretion of mostly neutrons but sometimes protons onto lighter nuclei.  The original nickel was radioactive and decayed to cobalt, then iron.  Radioactive decays were necessary to bring these new nuclei into the realm of nuclear stability.  That is why all rocks are still radioactive.  The supernova made all radioactive elements including plutonium, cesium 137, etcetera.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Radiation also comes from outer space in the form of cosmic rays.  Cosmic rays come from supernovas that are very far away.  There will always be cosmic rays.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Again: 4 Billion years ago, the Earth was a lot more radioactive than it is today.  There is no place in or on Earth or in space where there is no radiation.  There never was.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332343">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332343">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332343">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332343">
                  sferrin
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332343">

                  Getting your average Apple product user in a room with anything remotely related to nuclear would be a miracle in itself.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332442">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332442">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332442">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332442">
                  P.B. Lecavalier
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332442">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332442">
                 <p>
                  A fascinating technology. So whats the power density, in terms of Watt-hour/kg, and how much could it cost to manufacture, per Watt-hour? If its protective casing is paramount and somewhat fragile, then it could be suitable for stationary applications in remote or industrial areas, and make those intermittent renewable power sources far more effective.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332565">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332565">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332565">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332565">
                  Kaya
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332565">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332565">
                 <p>
                  Gamma radiation isnt only stopped by dense materials like lead or concrete.  All matter stops it including air. It depends on the exact frequency but as little as 5 meters of air can half gamma radiation.  So if the source is 50 meters away only 0.1% of the radiation will get to you and that is before you also take into account the inverse square law which again greatly reduces the amount.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The beta battery doesnt make sense for mobiles but maybe for HGVs or UAVs or Shipping assuming the weight to power ratio os suitable which it probably isnt
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->

        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=190555';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };

           </script>

           </p>

			&lt;script type="text/javascript"&gt;
    window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
           </script>

      u=h==="https:"?"d1z2jf7jlzjs58.cloudfront.net"
      :"static."+p+".com";

  e = d.createElement(s); e.id = i; e.async = true;

           <!-- chartbeat -->
           <script type="text/javascript">
            var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Computing'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Sebastian Anthony';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
           </script>

           <script type="text/javascript">
            jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});
           </script>

     <!-- This website is patched against a big problem not solved from WordPress 2.5+ to date -->
     <script type="text/javascript">
      // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
     </script>
